On the occassion of World day to combat desertification and drought,as the world fights a pandemic and nature tries it's best to heal back to health... join in for the national webinar organized by Regional Museum of Natural History Bhubaneswar over Goto meeting at 10:30 AM. 
The burning issue of land degradation and desertification is bound to touch all our lives sooner.or later. Let's discuss our little roles and contribution we can put in to save the planet from shattering further. For all the wrong already done let's find out how can we help earth heal back to health. It's not our duty only. It's a dire need of the hour. For the fast depleting green cover , more than 20 states in India are already facing land degradation! What doesn't seem to affect us right away is slowing ailing the planet and thus all of us. Time to act!

Tomorrow is Desertification and Drought Day. Due to the consequences of climate change, aridity in sub-Saharan Africa is getting worse every year. Agroecology could be an additional weapon for protecting local cultures. This interesting idea of circular agriculture management brings together organic farming and the breeding of animals for the production of fertilizer. A reportage from Burkina Faso by mirko_cecchi.

Tomorrow is World Day to Combat Desertification and Drought.

"Current commitments from over 100 countries specify the restoration of almost 1 billion hectares of land over the next decade ‚Äì an area almost the size of China. If we restore this land, we can deliver massive benefits for people and the planet."

The United Nations Convention to Combat Desertification (UNCCD) has various activities and materials on its website. Learn more: https://www.un.org/en/observances/desertification-day

Tomorrow being #worlddesertificationday ,GGI is committed to rooting out #desertification by planting trees.

The Middle East and North Africa (MENA) region is one of the driest regions in the world. Though farmers have navigated the drought-prone climate for millennia, they are now facing new challenges of an extended, and more severe dry season due to climate change.

Lebanon üá±üáß saw a historic drought in 2014 leading to towns having to purchase water from tankers; Morocco üá≤üá¶ used to see drought once per decade but they are now two to three times more common; and Jordan üáØüá¥ is now considered to be the second most water-deprived country in the world. 

IWMI‚Äôs MENAdrought project seeks to empower stakeholders across Jordan, Lebanon, and Morocco to anticipate, prepare for, and mitigate the impacts of drought on water and food systems.üåßüåø

Visit our website to learn more.

Tomorrow will be the 2021 Desertification and Drought Day, which will focus on turning degraded land into healthy land. It helps biodiversity to recover. It locks away the atmospheric carbon warming the Earth, slowing climate change. It can also lessen the impacts of climate change and underpin a green recovery from the COVID-19 pandemic, which is also our design purpose.

Desertification occurs when arid, semi-arid and dry  areas are subject to degradation caused primarily by human activities and climatic variations. Dryland ecosystems are extremely prone to overexploitation and inappropriate land use. 
Poverty, political instability, deforestation, overgrazing and bad irrigation practices are some major reasons that can¬† undermine the productivity of the land. This day reminds that cooperation and intervention is required at all levels to combat desertification.
